messages.subject: Re: Tsuba questions
messages.msgSnippet: Just a little chronology with help from Dr. Torigoye. Apparently the Ko-Shoami School developed out of the Katchushi tsubako in the late Muromachi Jidai.
messages.messageBody:
Just a little chronology with help from Dr. Torigoye.
Apparently the Ko-Shoami School developed out of the Katchushi tsubako
in the late Muromachi Jidai. After the hostilities ended with Edo
Jidai emerging there was a dispersal of the Shoami School to different
regions of Japan with the remaining Kyoto artisans being the Kyo-
Shoami. (Kyo-sukashi and Heianjo-sukashi developed in Kyoto during
Momoyama Jidai and into Edo until they more or less merged).
Just a note -- the tsuba of Petter could also very well be Bizen Shoami
as they had similar styles with the Kyo-Shoami in sukashi and nunome.
Dr. Torigoye mentioned the mimi thickness was a delineating point of
reference, the Bizen being slightly thicker. I am not certain if this
style was used in the Ko-Shoami but a note of interest is that the gold
nunome of the older pieces apparently was accomplished with greater
skill so that pieces of greater age often have more of the nunome left
as opposed to the later Edo school pieces.
(OK -- did I get that right, Jim?)(BIG LOL)

messages.subject: Re: Tsuba questions
messages.msgSnippet: Hi Petter, ok. That s a nice tsuba for $10.00, be very happy with it. Kyo  does refer to Kyoto, as Kyoto was the political hub of Japan during the Muromachi
messages.messageBody:
Hi Petter, ok. That's a nice tsuba for $10.00, be very happy with it.

Kyo does refer to Kyoto, as Kyoto was the political hub of Japan during
the Muromachi period. So Kyo Sukashi works may have started in the mid
late 1400's but I am unsure if Kyo Shoami started that early but they
certainly began in the late Muromachi era.

You guard looks typical of the late 17th to early 18th century pieces I
think. That's just my hunch. I may be wrong.

Hitsu ana Ume were used to fill the Hitsu ana when there were no Kozuka
or Kogai used on the koshirae. It was an aesthetic thing I think. No
need for holes when there's nothing to put in them. In your tsubas case,
there would have been a Kozuka, but no Kogai, so the Kogai hole was
filled, with Shakudo covered copper mostly.

The Sekigane that fills the nakago ana is a packer or filler to ensure
the blade fits snugly on the nakago. This tsuba was most likely been
fitted to a second or even third sword in it's life.

I have seen furniture from the Meiji period were tsuba have been mounted
in door of cabinets and the likes but I don't think they wore them as
pendants if that's what you mean :-) I think they were used mostly as
tsuba. Though I think a few very special pieces ( Maybe Ko Goto and the
likes ) were probably stored away and kept in safe places.

There were not to many wars in Japan after the Tokugawa took over so it
is unlikely this tsuba has seen battle, unless a one on one.

hope that helps some.

Richard

messages.subject: Re: Tsouba newbie
messages.msgSnippet: ... Thanks for the quick replies, Richard and klepet. I ve uploaded better pictures at http://tinyurl.com/8vzen and http://tinyurl.com/brcqz . My mother only
messages.messageBody:
--- In nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com, Richard Turner <ikkanshi@w...>
wrote:
>
> Hi Peter, welcome to the group. My guess would be that it is
> Shoami, and most probably, Kyo Shoami. Nice floral these, we
> can't tell a lot about the iron due to the colour of your
> photo's unfortunately but if in good condition without cracks
> or serous damage, then this sort of thing might
> sell on Ebay for between $300 - $400.00

Thanks for the quick replies, Richard and klepet. I've uploaded better
pictures at http://tinyurl.com/8vzen and http://tinyurl.com/brcqz . My
mother only paid about $10 for it.

I've got a couple of questions, if you don't mind.

If it's Kyo Shoami, does that mean it was made in Kyoto? Am I right in
guessing that it's from the early Edo period? 1650ish?

The Kogai Hitsu-ana is filled out like on many other Tsuba I've seen
pictures of online. Was this done to enforce the structure or as part
of repairs or for some other reason? Would it have happened much later
in time? The same goes for the fillers in the Nakago-ana.

Were all Tsuba mounted on weapons or were they used elsewhere as e.g.
decoration? Any chance mine might've seen battle? :-)

I'm reading up on the topic, but I'm sure I'll think of other
questions.

Thanks again,

Petter

messages.subject: Re: Tsouba newbie
messages.msgSnippet: Hi!  I would agree with Rich on it being Kyo-Shoami.
messages.messageBody: Hi! I would agree with Rich on it being Kyo-Shoami.

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Tsouba newbie
messages.msgSnippet: Hi Peter, welcome to the group. My guess would be that it is Shoami, and most probably, Kyo Shoami. Nice floral these, we can t tell a lot about the iron due
messages.messageBody:
Hi Peter, welcome to the group. My guess would be that it is Shoami, and
most probably, Kyo Shoami. Nice floral these, we can't tell a lot about
the iron due to the colour of your photo's unfortunately but if in good
condition without cracks or serous damage, then this sort of thing might
sell on Ebay for between $300 - $400.00

Jim's site has a section on Shoami tsuba I believe.

Cheers

Richard

messages.subject: Tsouba newbie
messages.msgSnippet: Hi all. I found this group via the excellent http://home.earthlink.net/ ~jggilbert/tsuba.htm and I was hoping you could tell me a bit about my first tsuba. A
messages.messageBody:
Hi all.

I found this group via the excellent http://home.earthlink.net/
~jggilbert/tsuba.htm and I was hoping you could tell me a bit about my
first tsuba. A relative picked it up at a flea market, hoping to mount
it on a drawer, but now it's mine :-).

I've looked through the above site, but I'm having trouble both dating
it and determining the style. I know the leaves and flower are
chrysanthemum, but that's about it. It's 85 mm (3.35 in) in diameter
and weighs 96 gram (3.39 oz). I can't find any characters engraved on
either side or the rim. I'm guessing it's made of iron with patches of
gold leaf.

The link to the front is http://tinyurl.com/d9fvq and to the back is
http://tinyurl.com/b6643 . My lack of photography skills is legendary,
so please ignore the level differences and let me know if better
pictures are required.

I doubt there's much market in my area for this type of item and I'm
definitely keeping it for the novelty, but I'd be curious to know if
it's worth 50 cents or 5 dollars.

That's all for now, thanks in advance for any comments.

Petter
